A simple slow cooked ragu, with italian herbs and seasonings. Pork and Beef mince is used here. You can use only beef if preferred, and make it lean by using lean steak mince. The latter helps lower the fat content.

The secret to this recipe is to use ground meat. Shop bought mince and butcher's mince comes out of processing quite stringy. I prefer to process the meat further by "grounding" the meat.

This involves adding the dry ingredients (seasonings) and a splash of balsamic vinegar, in a bowl and mixing with your hands. You literally grind the meat through your hands, gently squeezing and breaking the meat down further. This helps the meat tenderise more and gives a smoother texture to the ragu.

I always use ground meat mince, be it for pies, pasta dishes, chillis, curries or burgers. Stringy bits of meat just looks awful and the texture is not great.

It helps with the luxuriousness of the finished dish.

Of course you can use a meat processor and make your own mince, its often nice to also use whole chunks of beef (cubes). What also works well in this dish is using left over roast beef, from your Sunday lunch. Tear apart, cube into chunks or roughly chop.

Serve with Tagletelli.

Prep

  1. Dice the onion and grate the carrot.
  2. Add diced onion, carrot, pepper, paprika, salt, and balsamic to the mince and hand mix to create ground mince. Leave to one side until ready to cook.

Method (Ragu)

  1. Add the ground meat to a pan and brown off.
  2. Drain any fat in a environmentally safe manner.
  3. If using wine add it and cook off for a few minutes mixing in thoroughly into the meat.
  4. Add the rest of the ingredients and bring to a high heat, then reduce to a simmer.
  5. Simmer on a stove for 1 hour or add to the slow cooker for at least 2 hrs.
  6. Top up with Chicken stock if needs be during the cook.

Serving

  1. About 20 minutes before serving, cook the tagalatelli in a pan of water. Add a pinch of salt and a drop of olive oil.
  2. Once at the required consistency, as per the packet instruction. Drain and rest.
  3. Ladel some of the ragu onto the taglatelli and fold in.
  4. Serve with the rest immediatley
  5. Garnish with basil and cheese.

Nutrition

Luxurious Upgrade

To take this to another level try the following options:

  • Blitz a red bell pepper and add it to step 1 in the Method above.
  • Scorch/Roast some garlic/ and a red pepper and add to the ragu before simmering.

Tips

  • This can be refigerated for 3-4 days and re-heated. Why not add it to a baked potato for lunch.
  • Or Freeze the leftovers. Ensure you thaw completely before serving.
  • The frozen ragu can be used as a base for a Chilli or Mince Keema Curry, at a later date.
  • When roasting meat, ensure you use any bones, carcasses that are left to make a wholesome stock, soup or broth.
